pullRequest.body:
Adds basic API for presentations of algebras and constructors for localization and base change.

This contribution was created as part of the AIM workshop "Formalizing algebraic geometry" in June 2024.

Co-authored-by: Andrew Yang @erdOne
Co-authored-by: Jung Tao Cheng @rontaucheng 

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body:
### PR summary [d93929f0eb](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/14271/commits/d93929f0eb74899157c87efb0b72f722cf5dc93d)

#### Import changes

Dependency changes

| File | Base Count | Head Count | Change |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Mathlib.RingTheory.MvPolynomial.Localization | 989 | 1023 | +34 (+3.44%) |
| Mathlib.RingTheory.Generators | 1152 | 1155 | +3 (+0.26%) |

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ Algebra.Presentation`
`+ IsFinite`
`+ aeval_val_relation`
`+ auxHom`
`+ auxInv`
`+ dimension`
`+ finitePresentation_of_isFinite`
`+ ideal_fg_of_isFinite`
`+ instance [P.IsFinite] : FinitePresentation R P.Quotient`
`+ ker_eq_ker_aeval_val`
`+ localizationAway_dimension_zero`
`+ localizationAway_isFinite`
`+ mk'_pow`
`+ mvPolynomialQuotientEquiv`
`+ mvPolynomialQuotientEquiv_apply`
`+ quotientEquiv`
`+ quotientEquiv_mk`
`+ quotientEquiv_symm`
`+ sec`
`+ sec_spec`
`++ baseChange`
`++ localizationAway`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/no_lost_declarations.sh short <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/no_lost_declarations.sh <optional_commit>
```
</details>

</details>
Thanks for the quick reviews!

A question for native English speakers: Which is correct?
* "A `R`-algebra" 
* "An `R`-algebra"

My gut feeling says it's the second one (since it corresponds to what I would say when reading it), but I wouldn't want to claim I know all the rules.

> A question for native English speakers: Which is correct?
> 
> * "A `R`-algebra"
> * "An `R`-algebra"
> 
> My gut feeling says it's the second one (since it corresponds to what I would say when reading it), but I wouldn't want to claim I know all the rules.

Definitely "an `R`-algebra". Indeed the rule is "write what you would say", and what you say depends on the sound not the actual letter (so e.g. "a eucalyptus tree" as the word is pronounced "Yucaliptus")

> > A question for native English speakers: Which is correct?
> > 
> > * "A `R`-algebra"
> > * "An `R`-algebra"
> > 
> > My gut feeling says it's the second one (since it corresponds to what I would say when reading it), but I wouldn't want to claim I know all the rules.
> 
> Definitely "an `R`-algebra". Indeed the rule is "write what you would say", and what you say depends on the sound not the actual letter (so e.g. "a eucalyptus tree" as the word is pronounced "Yucaliptus")

Fixed.
LGTM. What does @MichaelStollBayreuth think?
maintainer merge
ðŸš€ Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by MichaelStollBayreuth.

Thanks!

bors merge
Thanks for all the reviews!

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/9741048687/job/26879418782)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/9741048687/job/26879418530)
LGTM!
LGTM!

```suggestion
/-- For `s : S` with `S` being the localization away from `f`,
this is a choice of `(r, n) : R Ã— â„•` such that `s * algebraMap R S (f ^ n) = algebraMap R S r`. -/
```

Where is `x` in the statement? What is `r`?
Also, `x` is a `variable` here, so the name `x` should not be used to describe something else.

Did you mean to say

"For `s : S`, this is a choice of `(r, n) : R Ã— â„•` such that `s * algebraMap R S (x ^ n) = algebraMap R S r`" ?

(I.e., express `s` as `r/x^n` informally.)
I think the names of these two are too similar and might be confusing. Maybe make `relations` -> `rels` to mimic `vars`.
I'd reverse it and call it `span_range_relation_eq_ker`.

```suggestion
@[simp] lemma algebraMap_relation (i) : aeval P.val (P.relation i) = 0 := by
```
Should this also be `private`? It uses a private definition in the statement, which will then not be understandable outside this file.
Surely, this should be `Algebra.Presentation.dimension` ?

```suggestion
    RingHom.ker (aeval val) = Ideal.span (Set.range relation)
```
Left-over from a previous version?

```suggestion
Note: this definition is completely non-sensical for non-finite presentations and
even then for this to make sense, you should assume that the presentation
is a complete intersection.
```

```suggestion
lemma ideal_eq_span_range_relation : P.ker = Ideal.span (Set.range P.relation) :=
```

```suggestion
/-- A presentation is finite if there are only finitely-many
```

```suggestion
/-- The polynomial algebra wrt a family of generators modulo a family of relations. -/
```

```suggestion
lemma finitePresentation_of_isFinite [P.IsFinite] :
```
This is already in the `Presentation` namespace right?
Not sure how robust is `simp; rfl`. Maybe squeeze it.
Similarly.
One could write the `fun i â†¦ ...` part more concisely as `(MvPolynomial.map (algebraMap R T)) âˆ˜ P.relation`, but I haven't checked if this makes things better or worse later.
It seems to make things worse, so I left it as is.

An alternative (which is just alternative notation, AFAIK) is
`((MvPolynomial.map (algebraMap R T)) (P.relation Â·))` .
(But this is not really important...)
The scope of `Â·` seems to be interpreted as restricted to `P.relation`, so this causes a type error.
Can these be combined into a single `erw`?

```suggestion
  relation : rels â†’ toGenerators.Ring
```

```suggestion
    toGenerators.ker = Ideal.span (Set.range relation)
```
I wonder if we should just call it `span_range_relation_eq_ker` and replace the lemma below.
You mean, state this the other way round?
Yes.
Done.

```suggestion
lemma aeval_val_relation (i) : aeval P.val (P.relation i) = 0 := by
```
Working with the `Generators` api a bit more, I've come to realize having simp lemmas on the indexing types are not a good thing. Maybe make `rels` `lemmasOnly`.

```suggestion
@[simps relation]
def baseChange : Presentation T (T âŠ—[R] S) where
```
Similar here. `vars` should not be simp IMO.

```suggestion
@[simps! val]
def baseChange {T} [CommRing T] [Algebra R T] (P : Generators R S) : Generators T (T âŠ—[R] S) := by
```

```suggestion
## Notes
This contribution was created as part of the AIM workshop
"Formalizing algebraic geometry" in June 2024.

```
I think we can remove this.

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(RingTheory): presentations of algebras
